Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in failing to assess the applicant's practice of Christianity
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to religious persecution as a member of an underground Christian church in China
Decision_Outcome: Board denied refugee status based on credibility concerns regarding membership, but did not assess actual religious practice
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Court_Ruling: Application for judicial review allowed; matter referred to a different panel for redetermination
Defendant_Behavior: Board failed to assess whether the applicant was a practicing Christian
Grounds_for_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution based on religion under IRPA
Legal_Standard: Convention refugee definition requiring well-founded fear of persecution on grounds of religion
Assessment_Factor: Credibility of religious practice and membership in an underground church
Review_Standard: Patent unreasonableness standard applied to credibility findings
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant not credible on membership but did not assess actual practice of Christianity
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony regarding participation in an underground church
Application_Basis: Fear of religious persecution in China
Evidence_Assessed: Membership in underground church, lack of assessment on religious practice
Relief_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a new Board panel
Governing_Rule: Under IRPA, a Convention refugee must have a well-founded fear of persecution based on religion
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess whether the applicant practiced Christianity despite claiming religious persecution
Outcome: Case remitted to a new panel for redetermination
Harm_Assessment: Risk of persecution due to religious belief in country of origin
Cause_Description: Applicant claimed persecution as a practicing Christian in China, particularly as a member of an underground church
Evidence_Handling: Insufficient analysis of evidence related to personal religious practice
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA provisions relating to refugee determination and protection based on religion
Evidence_Issues: Lack of inquiry into actual religious practice despite central relevance to claim
Legal_Provision: IRPA, subsection 72(1); Article 1A(2) of the Refugee Convention
Evidence_Assessment: Board assessed credibility of church membership but omitted assessment of religious practice
Decision_Rationale: Omission in assessing religious practice affected the fairness and completeness of the refugee determination
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to address key element of religious practice in assessing persecution claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on the basis of religion
